bestBHT.bht: During the winter feast, a true shepherd, recognized by God, enters in by the door leading the sheep. This is in stark contrast to the conduct of the Pharisees and signifies Christ's role as the protector of his flock. He is not referring solely to himself, but to all ministers of the gospel who enter in the same manner, showing that they come to care for and feed the sheep, not to kill and destroy. This characteristic of shepherding holds true for any under shepherd who has his mission and authority derived from Christ.

Henry Alford: This feast had become usual since the time when Judas Maccabæus purified the temple from the profanations of Antiochus."
It was held on Chisleu (December) 25, and seven following days: see 1 Mace. iv. 41–59: 2 Mace. x. 1–8."
It was winter. The notice is inserted to explain to Gentile readers the reason of our Lord’s walking in Solomon’s portico.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 2. he that entereth in by the door
is the shepherd of the sheep—a true, divinely recognized
Albert Barnes: He that entereth by the door...become ministers of religion.
Christ does not here refer to himself...he refers to all the ministers of the gospel.
By his entering in this manner he shows that he is a shepherd...does not come to kill and destroy.
Marvin Vincent: The shepherd [ποιμην] . Better, a shepherd. It is the character rather than the person that is contemplated.
Archibald T. Robertson: He comes in by the door with the sheep whom he leads.
Old word is ποιμην, root meaning to protect.
Christ is drawing a sharp contrast after the conduct of the Pharisees towards the blind man between himself and them.
John Gill: But he that entereth in by the door... he is the shepherd of the sheep.
By whom Christ means himself... who takes care of them, and feeds them, as a shepherd does his flock.
Which holds true of any under shepherd, having his mission and commission, and deriving his authority from Christ.

bhtAttempts.bht: During the winter feast, a true shepherd, recognized by God, enters in by the door leading the sheep. This is in stark contrast to the conduct of the Pharisees and signifies Christ's role as the protector of his flock. He is not referring solely to himself, but to all ministers of the gospel who enter in the same manner, showing that they come to care for and feed the sheep, not to kill and destroy. This characteristic of shepherding holds true for any under shepherd who has his mission and authority derived from Christ.

During the winter feast, a true shepherd enters in by the door, recognized by God, leading the sheep. This starkly contrasts with the conduct of the Pharisees and highlights Christ's role as the protector. He is referring not just to himself, but to all ministers of the gospel who demonstrate the same characteristics. They come to care for and nourish the sheep, not to harm them. This holds true for any under shepherd who has their mission and authority derived from Christ.

During the winter feast, a true shepherd enters in by the door, recognized by God, leading the sheep. Christ draws a contrast between himself and the Pharisees, emphasizing his role as protector. He refers not only to himself, but to all ministers of the gospel who exhibit the same caring attributes. They come to nourish and nurture the sheep, rather than causing harm. This applies to any under shepherd who derives their mission and authority from Christ.

During the winter feast, a true shepherd enters in by the door, recognized by God, leading the sheep. Christ draws a sharp contrast between himself and the Pharisees, highlighting his role as the protector. He refers not only to himself but to all ministers of the gospel, emphasizing their mission to care for and nourish the sheep instead of causing harm. This holds true for any under shepherd who derives their authority from Christ, demonstrating the characteristics of a shepherd and ensuring the well-being of the flock.

During the winter feast, a true shepherd, recognized by God, enters in by the door leading the sheep. Christ contrasts himself with the Pharisees, emphasizing his role as the protector. All ministers of the gospel are included in his reference, highlighting their mission to care for and nourish the sheep rather than harming them. This applies to any under shepherd who derives their authority from Christ, ensuring the well-being of the flock and exemplifying the characteristics of a true shepherd.
